patterns: Why was Mrs. Vijaylakshmi Pandit in anguish?
responses: Mrs. Vijaylakshmi Pandit had lost her husband and she had no son to inherit share of her in-laws’ family.

patterns: In paragraph 3
Mrs. Pandit speaks about “antiquated law.” What is referred to as antiquated law?
responses: “Antiquated law” refers that only male heirs had the right to inherit the family property. Female heirs didn’t have any right to inherit the property.

patterns: Why was Mrs. Pandit going to America according to Gandhiji?
responses: According to Gandhiji
Mrs. Pandit was going to America because she was unhappy and wanted to escape from her plight.

patterns: What did Gandhiji want Mrs. Pandit to do before going abroad? What was Mrs. Pandit’s response to that?
responses: Gandhiji wanted Mrs. Pandit to meet her family and bid good-bye to them before going abroad because courtesy and decency demanded this.

patterns: How did Gandhiji make Mrs. Pandit meet her relatives?
responses: Gandhiji advised Mrs. Pandit to let go of her bitterness that she had in her heart. He told her to be humble and cleanse her heart before going abroad.

patterns: “Must you inflict further injury on yourself” What is the injury referred to here?
responses: The injury is the pain by the bitterness in the heart of Mrs. Pandit.

patterns: Why did Gandhiji ask Mrs. Pandit not to hurt herself?
responses: Gandhiji asked Mrs. Pandit not to hurt herself because she was already in the pain of the death of her husband. By keeping bitterness in her heart would make add further injury.

intents.tags: mrs pandit, not meet, beginning, america
patterns: Why did Mrs. Pandit not meet her relatives in the beginning before she left for America?
responses: In the beginning Mrs.Pandit didn’t want to meet her relatives because she had bitter feelings toward them as she and her daughters were not considered as heirs in their family property and the relatives didn’t support her.

patterns: “I lifted the debate back to where it belonged.” What was the debate about?
responses: The debate was about India’s complaint regarding the treatment of people of Indian origin in South Africa.

patterns: Mrs. Pandit recollected the advice of Gandhiji often. What was the advice?
responses: No one can harm you but yourself- this was the advice that Mrs. Pandit often recollected.

patterns: After visiting her relatives
Mrs. Pandit commented
‘‘I felt as if a great burden had been lifted and I was free to be myself.”’
responses: Yes

I had been in such situation when I demanded useless thing from my father. He tried to explain me but I became angry. After a few days when I realized that it was mistake I felt guilty of hurting my father and apologized to him. Only after apologizing him I felt as if a great burden had been lifted.

patterns: What do you infer about the relationship between Mrs. Pandit and Gandhiji from reading this lesson?
responses: From reading the lesson we come to understand that Mrs. Pandit had huge respect towards Gandhiji and she took his advice seriously. She followed his advice.

patterns: Describe the state of mind of the cook referred to in the lesson
responses: The cook was completely drunk and had no control on what he was doing. He was waving a ladle and singing
beating time with his foot. His eyes were glazed and he was far away in some other sphere. The table was littered with pieces of chicken.

patterns: Mrs. Pandit had to face a lot of humiliating situations in her life. Give a brief account of the situations and comment on them.
responses: Mrs. Pandit faced a lot of humiliation when she lost her husband. It was a law that only male heirs could inherit the property of the family. Mrs. Pandit didn’t have any son; she had two daughters which meant that she and her daughters would not inherit the property of the family. It made her feel sad about her situation. It created bitterness in her heart towards her relatives. Another situation when she faced a lot of humiliation was when she was in New York. She was the leader of the Indian delegation to the United Nations. Harsh things were said to her and her country which made her feel sad very deeply. The given both situations show how cruel the people had been with Mrs. Pandit yet she managed to stand strong and come back fearlessly.

patterns: Comment on the title of the lesson with respect to Mrs. Pandit’s experiences in different situations in her life.
responses: The title of the lesson- ‘The Best Advice I Ever Had’ aptly shows how Mrs. Pandit was greatly influenced by Gandhiji’s words and followed his advice at crucial stages of her life. Gandhiji’s advice that no one can hurt harm you except yourself paved her right way and she had a cordial relation with her relatives.

patterns: From a reading of the lesson
write a note on Mrs. Pandit’s accomplishments and her contributions to India.
responses: Mrs. Pandit was the High Commissioner for India in the United Kingdom. She was also the first woman President of the UN General Assembly. She was a leader of the Indian delegation to the United Nations.

intents.tags: means are as important as the end, gandhiji, agree
patterns: “Means are as important as the end
” said Gandhiji. Do you agree with this view? Justify your answer.
responses: Here Gandhiji wanted to tell that the process of anything to achieve is as important as the result. It is very important that the process is also paid attention as much as we think about the outcome. It was because of his words that helped Mrs. Pandit achieve bigger goals and become successful in life.

patterns: Assume yourself to be a social activist. Write an article suggesting ways and means of removing gender discrimination that
responses: Women are the real architects of the society. They play a key role in building the society. Still in India we can see the problem of gender discrimination and gender inequality. Women now are as equal as men in almost every field of life. But still there are some people who think that women should only be at home and look after their family. They fail to recognize the strength a woman has.It is very important to spread awareness regarding equal rights for women as many women don’t even know their basic rights. It is important to make people realize that women have wishes and passion to follow and one should give them freedom. We must respect woman and her decision and give her wings to fly and follow her dream.

patterns: Where is Mauritius?
responses: Mauritius is a tiny island situated below the Equator in the Indian Ocean. It is 4
500 km away from south-west of Bombay (Mumbai).

patterns: Name the people of different origins found in Mauritius.
responses: People of different origins found in Mauritius are Africans
Chinese
Biharis
Dutch
Persians
Tamils
Arabs
French and English.

patterns: Who are referred to as the “buccaneering trinity” of those days? Why are they called so?
responses: The Dutch

the French and the English are referred to as the “buccaneering trinity.” They are called so because they constantly waged battle for the possession of the island for its spices and sugar or just for the strategic position on the maritime route to the East.

patterns: List out some “very musical but unpronounceable names” as found by the author.
responses: Trouaux Biches
Beau Bassin
Quarter Bornes
Curepipe
Ross Belle are some “very musical but unpronounceable names” as found by the author.

patterns: What are the “flora and fauna” found in Mauritius?
responses: Mauritius doesn’t have much of mammal. Bat was the only mammal on this island before man. The trees here are short and gnarled even in the interior of jungles
looking just like abnormally overgrown bonsai. The birds are dwindling in number and variety. The dodo
a bird which could not fly and which certainly had no claims to beauty and elegance
was a native of this island and mercifully is extinct now. And so are the giant tortoises of the Aldabra variety.

patterns: How is Nature cruel to the people of Mauritius?
responses: The people of Mauritius are used to facing the storms as they are an annual event in Mauritius. The big ones come only once in 15 years. They are called the King Cyclone. After the disaster people rebuild their buildings
houses.

patterns: Name some aquatic creatures sighted by the author.
responses: Some aquatic creatures sighted by the author are crabs
lobsters
snaky forms and fishes.

patterns: Why was it difficult for the author to locate Mauritius in his Atlas?
responses: The author had an old Atlas with him. It had little dots and specks on it. It was not in good condition due to weather and cockroaches so it didn’t prove to be helpful for the author to locate Mauritius in his Atlas.

intents.tags: people, different countries, settle in mauritius
patterns: What is the reason for the people of different countries to settle in Mauritius?
responses: People from the different origins settle in Mauritius because there is sense of oneness and people live happily with each other. People respect the differences of other and live merrily.

intents.tags: absence of protocol, government officials, ministers
patterns: How does the author explain the absence of protocol among the government officials and ministers in Mauritius?
responses: In Mauritius the Cabinet Ministers and others in high positions do not act superior. They are just like ordinary people. They are unassuming
accessible
communicative and above all
go about without any security. The residence of the Prime Minister of Mauritius is a modest flat in a busy street lined with shops and crawling traffic..

patterns: Give the description of mountains as given by the author.
responses: The mountains in Mauritius do not have the traditional monotonous pyramidal shapes. Their outlines are freakish and whimsical with unexpected sweeps and perpendicular drops and pin-pointed peaks precariously doing a balancing act with boulders as big as a skyscraper.

intents.tags: fight against, cruel jaws of nature
patterns: How are the people of Mauritius described fighting against the cruel jaws of Nature?
responses: Cyclones and storms as so common in Mauritius that people are used to it. The big storm known as the King Cyclone comes once in 15 years and destroys everything. People have to rebuild their houses and plant trees again.

patterns: What would be the future of Mauritius as opined by the author?
responses: There are many thoughts that come in the mind of the author when he leaves Mauritius. He thinks about its future. He thinks that will it be able to preserve its pristine charm. Though it is eager to have foreign entrepreneurs start their industries here
but the chances are of increasing cost of living
problems of unemployment
etc. The author is worried that if there is increase in industrialization then the serene beauty of Mauritius would be lost.

patterns: Compare and contrast the arriving and departing experiences of the author during his flight. Does it suggest anything to you?
responses: When the author arrives in Mauritius

he is happy and excited to experience a whole new world and people. He is amazed to see how people from the different origins live merrily. He is attracted and charmed by its pristine beauty. He is also amazed by the facts that how nature is cruel to the people of Mauritius and despite that people come back strong and live together. But at the time of the departure
the author thinks deeply about its future. He thinks about whether it will be the same pristine and beautiful if there is industrialization and foreign entrepreneurship.

patterns: Why was the group looking for a shelter?
responses: The group was looking for a shelter because it was raining.

patterns: How far was the village from the place the group was living in?
responses: The village was three miles away from the place where the group was living in.

patterns: Why did Mr. Hunt hesitate to seek shelter in the house?
responses: Mr. Hunt hesitated to seek shelter in the house because he thought that it was a lonely place to live.

patterns: Name the occupants of the house.
responses: The occupants of the house were Mr. and Mrs. Brown.

intents.tags: pretext, occupants, separate, teachers from children
patterns: On what pretext did the occupants of the house separate the teachers from the children?
responses: The occupants told that the room was not enough for everyone so they made the teachers to sit in the sitting room.

patterns: What seemed unnatural in the house to the children?
responses: The unusual things about the house were that it had not washing-up machines
plates
pots
pans which are very common in any normal house.

patterns: What was unnatural with Mrs. Brown’s hand?
responses: The unnatural thing with Mrs. Brown’s hand was that she had seven fingers on both her hands.

patterns: What did the children find in the larger cupboard?
responses: The children found dials
digital read-outs
coloured lights and a mass of other electronic equipment.

patterns: When Pete went to Mr. Hunt
Pete heard the Browns talking to each other but could not understand what they were saying. Why?
responses: Pete couldn’t understand what Browns were talking about because they were sounded as if they were just sort of hissing and clicking at each other.

patterns: Why did Pete prevent the other children from taking the drink?
responses: Pete prevented the other children from taking the drink because it could have made them drugged.

patterns: Where were the aliens taking the children?
responses: The aliens were taking the children to their home planet.

patterns: Why were the aliens collecting the creatures from other planets?
responses: The aliens were collecting the creatures from other planets for experiment and scientific study.

patterns: Where was the control of the backdoor located?
responses: The control of the backdoor was located in the cupboard.

patterns: After sending all the others out of the spaceship
how did Pete and Glenn manage to escape from the aliens?
responses: Glen smashed the control panel and both the boys ran from the back door.

patterns: What circumstances forced the party to take shelter in the spaceship?
responses: The party was completely wet due to the rain and this made them take shelter in the spaceship.

patterns: List the things that made the children feel uncomfortable in the kitchen.
responses: Everything in the kitchen was quite unusual. There was not washing-up machine
pots
plates and pAnswer: Even there was nothing in the fridge and the lights were off.

patterns: Why couldn’t the children escape either through the backdoor or the window?
responses: The children couldn’t escape either through the backdoor or the window because both had burglar proof lock.

patterns: What suspicion did the children have about the Browns and their ‘house’? What convincing reasons did Mrs. Brown come up with?
responses: The children found everything about the house especially the kitchen very unusual. There was no washing-up machine
pots

plates and pAnswer: The fridge had no lights and nothing in it. It didn’t work. There were electric equipments in the cupboard which was very odd. Mrs. Brown came up with the reason that they had recently moved there and didn’t have enough time to sort out the things out.

patterns: How did Pete become instrumental in saving the teachers and his mates?
responses: When the children realized that Mr. and Mrs. Brown were not humans but aliens they tried very hard to escape from there. When Pete questioned about the door and other things Mrs. Brown gave excuse which made them clear about their doubts. Pete asked Glen to take the stick and smash the control panel. It was Pete who pressed the control and opened the door. He and Glen rushed out of the back door fast and this is how he could save lives.

patterns: There are a few sentences which speak about the grandmother’s features. Pick out those sentences and write them.
responses: The grandmother was short
fat and slightly bent. Her face was a criss-cross of wrinkles running from everywhere to everywhere. Her silver locks were scattered untidily over her pale
puckered face and her lips constantly moved in inaudible prayer.

patterns: “… she used to get me ready for school.” How did the grandmother get the author ready for school?
responses: The grandmother used to wake him up in the morning. She would bathe him and dressed him. After that she would give him wooden slate
a tiny earthen ink-pot and a red pen
tie them all in a bundle and hand it to him. She would give him a thick
stale chapatti with a little butter and sugar spread on it him.

patterns: Why did the grandmother accompany the author to the school?
responses: The grandmother accompanied with the author because his school was attached to the temple and she used to sit in the temple and read scriptures.

patterns: “That was a turning point in our friendship.” What was the “turning point”?
responses: When the author’s parents settled comfortably in the city then they sent for the author and his grandmother and this is how it proved to be the turning point in author’s friendship with his grandmother.

patterns: What made the grandmother unhappy? Why?
responses: In the city
the author went to an English school. His grandmother asked what he had learnt in the school then he would say he learnt English words and little things of western science and learning
the law of gravity
Archimede’s principle
the world being round

etc which was not understood by her and she couldn’t help him with the lessons. These made the grandmother unhappy. She was also upset with the fact the school didn’t teach about God and the scriptures.

patterns: “The thought was almost revolting.” What is “the thought” referred to? Why does the author use the word ‘revolting’ to describe the thought?
responses: The author’s grandmother had once been young and pretty and even had a husband
and she was pretty and young this thought was revolting to the author. The author couldn’t imagine his grandmother being so young and pretty once as he had always seen her old and wrinkled.

patterns: How did the grandmother help the author as a boy during his school days?
responses: The grandmother used to wake him up in the morning and get him ready for school. She would sing her morning prayer while bathing him and dress him up. Then she would fetch his wooden slate which she had already washed and plastered with yellow chalk
a tiny earthen ink-pot and a red pen
tie them all in a bundle and hand it to him. She would accompany him to his school after his breakfast.

patterns: Describe the relation between animals/birds (dogs and sparrows) and the grandmother.
responses: The grandmother used to carry several stale chapattis with her for the village dogs while going to school. Even after moving to the city

she took to feeding sparrows in the courtyard of the city house. In the afternoon she would feed the sparrows. She would she sit in the verandah and break the bread into little bits and hundreds of little birds would gather around. She loved them so much she would never shooed them away.

intents.tags: three stages of relationship, between, author,  grandmother
patterns: Describe the three stages of relationship between the author and his grandmother (before he went abroad)
responses: When the author and his grandmother were in the village they had special bond. She used to look after him very well and did everything for him. They would go to school together and come back together. Their relationship took a turn when they both moved to the city. She felt upset that she couldn’t help him with his studies When the author went to university
there was a big gap between the two of them. He got his own room and this is how things started to change and his grandmother became quiet and spent most of her time with spinning wheel.

patterns: Grandmother and prayer were inseparable. Find instances from the lesson to justify this observation.
responses: When the author and the grandmother lived in the village

she would chant prayers while bathing him and getting him ready for school. When the author got separate room for himself she became quiet and would recite prayers sitting next to spinning wheel. When the grandmother went to see her grandson off to the abroad
even there she didn’t uttered a single word of farewell but she recited prayer. When the author arrived after five years
she clasped him in her arms and even at that time she recited her prayer. These incidents show that how deeply religious the grandmother was and how she always recited her prayers.

intents.tags: thumped, sagging, skins, dilapidated, drum, grandmother
patterns: ‘‘She thumped the sagging skins of the dilapidated drum.’’ Has the description of the drum anything to do with the grandmother? Explain.
responses: The author’s grandmother was very old and the drum she played was also old. Due to old age grandmother’s skin had become saggy. The phrase sagging skins focus on both the grandmother and the old drum played by her.

patterns: Did the grandmother predict her death? How?
responses: Yes

the grandmother did predict her death. She told the family members that there was only a few hours left before the last chapter of her life. She didn’t talk to anyone and just lay peacefully in bed praying and telling her beads.

patterns: How did the sparrows react to her earlier in her life and later after her death?
responses: When the grandmother moved to the city

there she used to feed the sparrows. She would sit in the verandah and break the bread into little bits and hundreds of little birds would come to her. They would perch on her legs but she never shooed them away. But when she passed away
thousands of sparrows sat scattered on the floor. They didn’t chirp as they used to when she was alive. The author’s mother fetched some bread for the sparrows
the way his grandmother used to do. But the sparrows didn’t even take notice of it. They just flew away quietly when the corpse was carried away.

patterns: What picture of the grandmother do you get from the lesson?
responses: The physical picture we get from the lesson is that the grandmother is old
fat and slightly bent. She has wrinkles all over her face. She is a pious woman who would chant prayers always. She had unconditional love for animals and birds.

patterns: Vikrant’s mother was harping on the importance of the year. What was she anxious about Vikrant?
responses: Vikrant’s mother thought that he should focus more on science and maths. She was of the opinion that class XI was important year for him to prepare well for his further studies. According to her he should study more in class XI as it was foundation year for class XII and using this as a practice year for launching into his twelfth board and medical entrance exams.

patterns: Anuj had spun into Vikrant’s life like a “new universe.” Why did Vikrant feel so? Who was Anuj?
responses: Anuj was Vikrant’s new friend who had dynamic ideas on photography. He also had the connectedness between human beings and all other living species
on self-improvement as a part of human evolution
on the cosmos.

patterns: The identity of Vikrant with Anuj created tension between Vikrant and his parents.” How did it happen?
responses: Vikrant’s parents being doctors themselves wanted Vikrant to be a doctor and for that they wanted him to completely concentrate only on studies rather than spending time with Anuj. They consider photography as prestigious and noble job. They wanted Vikrant only to prepare for his medical entrance and nothing else.

patterns: Vikrant said
“Medicine is considered ….. gives prestige.” Is this thought prejudiced? Do you agree with this opinion?
responses: The above thought is very much biased. Though medical profession is a good profession but that doesn’t imply that other professions are inferior. In the society we live there are many professions which help build the society and each profession has its own importance.

patterns: What was the reply of Anuj when Vikrant asked him how his suggestions would help him?
responses: Anuj answered Vikrant saying that
it will help him witness his reactions as if they were happening to someone else. By observing his body and its reactions
he can also distance himself from them. This distance will help him first see
then control his reactions.

patterns: When did Vikrant start his self-observation? What did he observe?
responses: When Vikrant’s father came up with the topic of Anuj and how Vikrant was wasting time with him and not focusing on studies
then Vikrant observed himself.The remark of his father sent a strong wave of heat through his otherwise weary body
galvanizing him to leave the room without another word.

patterns: How did Vikrant’s father try to convince him to join tuitions for medical entrance?
responses: Vikrant’s father wanted him to join tuitions for medical entrance. He said him that the tuitions for medical entrances were not just tuitions. They coach for a career
for a highly competitive exam. One wrong answer could make all the difference.

patterns: What are the last two steps of self-observation suggested by Anuj to Vikrant?
responses: The first step that Anuj told Vikrant was that when the moment an active feeling comes which he think should be controlled
then he should make a note of it
but don’t express it. And the second involved expressing an emotion opposite what he felt. In other words
if he felt agitated
then he had to choose to be clam.

patterns: ‘He did this with awareness that it was the right thing for him to do.’’ What does “awareness” refer to here?
responses: Here “awareness” refers to Vikrant’s realization of taking his entrance seriously for his sake. He enrolled for classes after his class XI realizing that it was the right thing for him to do.

patterns: The word
“Space” in the title of the lesson has a significant reference. Comment on the title.
responses: The word “Space” here emphasizes on our mind. If we balance between our mind and emotions
only then we would be able to focus on what we want in life. It is this space or balance of thinking which will lead us to better life ahead.

patterns: Compare and contrast the characters Vikrant and Anuj. Who would you like to be? Vikrat or Anuj? Justify your answer.
responses: Vikrant is a young boy studying in Class XI. His parents want him to doctor just like them. But he is kind of boy who is not clear in his approach and thoughts. He cannot take his parents’ pressure and gets dejected. He is someone who gets lost in his confused thoughts and cannot decide his directions. On the other hand his friend Anuj is wise and balanced. Anuj is much older than Vikrant. He is into photo journalism. His thoughts and ideas are clear and he has confidence. It is Anuj who is the guiding light in Vikrant’s life. Anuj advises him on how to control his emotions and how to be calm. He makes him clear in his thoughts and approach. He teachesVikrant to observe himself and bring changes in his life. I would like to be Anuj because his approach in life is simple and optimistic. He doesn’t have negative thoughts and is clear.

patterns: After Vikranth follows Anuj’s advice
we observe a change in his attitude and behaviour. Trace the chain of these changes.
responses: When Vikrant advised Anuj to observe himself and control emotion
then Vikrant follows the same. He observed his bodily changes when he became upset. He noticed that his mouth was dry
his head tight at the temples

his body slightly hunched. He realized that what Anuj told was right and felt to change the situation. It was then Anuj once again advised him react in opposite of what he felt. If he felt agitated then he should choose to remain calm. And Vikrant followed this too and to his surprise his body reacted in another way and there was much positive change in him. Even his parents started to take things from Vikrant’s side and this is how Anuj’s advice helped Vikrant get the right direction in his life.

patterns: What is the role played by Anuj in this lesson? What message does the author convey to the reader through this character?
responses: The role played by Anuj was the most important in Vikrant’s life. He was not only Vikrant’s friend but he became his mentor and brought positive changes in his life. It is because of Anuj that Vikrant starts observing himself and there is a positive change in his life. He advises Vikrant to stay calm and control his agitated emotions to get clear path. In this way Vikrant was able to enroll his name in entrance centre. Had it not been Anuj then Vikrant would have became confused and lost his right track in life. Anuj played a major role in changing life of Vikrant and his thoughts. The author wants to tell the readers that anyone can be our mentor and take us to the right path. We should not judge anyone based on his/her profession. In the lesson Vikrant’s parents judged him calling him junkie which was completely wrong. It was because of Anuj that Vikarnt’s thoughts became clearer and chose the right path.

patterns: Who owned the stories in the beginning?
responses: In the beginning the stories were owned by Nyame-the sky god.

patterns: Who wanted to own them later?
responses: Kwaku Anansi
the spider wanted to own them later.

patterns: What was the price to be paid to own all the stories in the world?
responses: The price to be paid to own all the stories were three things i.e. Mmoboro
the hornets and Onini
the great python.

patterns: Did Anansi agree to pay the price?
responses: Yes
Anansi agreed to pay the price.

patterns: Why did Anansi pour water on himself and over the hornets?
responses: Anansi poured water on himself and over the hornets to make hornets believe that it was raining.

patterns: What did Anansi capture the hornest in?
responses: Anansi captured the hornest in the gourd.

patterns: What dispute did the spider have with his wife?
responses: The spider’s wife argued with the spider that Onini
the python was shorter and weaker than the bamboo pole and the spider disagreed with her so they had dispute over it.

patterns: What suggestion did Onini give to find out the truth about his length and strength?
responses: Onini suggested Anansi to measure him against the bamboo pole to find out the truth about his length and strength.

patterns: Why did Anansi tie Onini at one end of the pole?
responses: Anansi saw that Onini was getting stretched at one end and getting shorter at the other end
so Anansi tied him at the front so that he wouldn’t slip.

patterns: Where and why did Anansi dig a pit?
responses: Anansi dug a pit in the forest to trap Oseba
the leopard.

patterns: Why did Anansi bend a tall green tree over a pit?
responses: Anansi bent a tall green tree over a pit to help Oseba come out of the pit.

patterns: Why did the Sky God offer Anansi all the stories?
responses: Ananasi proved himself to be a real hero by brining three creatures to the Sky God. It was something that was not done by anybody else before
so impressed by this
the Sky God offered Anansi all the stories.

patterns: Who should anyone acknowledge before telling a story?
responses: Anyone should acknowledge Anansi
the spider before telling a story.

patterns: Describe how Anansi captured the hornets for the Sky God.
responses: Firstly Anansi cut a gourd from a vine and made a small hole in it. Then he took a large calabash and filled it with water. He went to the tree where the hornets lived. He poured some of the water over himself
so that he was dripping. He threw some water over the hornets
so that they too were dripping. Then he put the calabash on his head
as though to protect himself from a storm

and called out to the hornets and asked why there were staying in the rain. Then the hornest asked where shall they go on which Anansi told them to get into the dry gourd.Then the hornets thanked him and flew into the gourd through the small hole. And finally when all of them entered in the gourd
he plugged the hole with a ball of grass.

patterns: Explain how the python got trapped.
responses: Anansi went to the forest and cut a long bamboo pole and some strong vines. Then he walked toward the house of Onini

the python. He talked to himself saying that his wife was stupid to think that the python was shorter and weaker than the bamboo. And Anansi disagreed with his wife. All this muttering of Anansi was heard by the python and he suggested him to measure against the bamboo. Anansi agreed and started to measure the python and said that he was stretching at one end. Then Anansi very smartly tied the python to the pole saying that in that way he wouldn’t slip and in this way he trapped the python.

patterns: What method did the spider Kwaku Anansi adopt to get the leopard demanded as a price for the ownership of all tales and stories of the world?
responses: Anansi went into the forest and dug a deep pit where the leopard was accustomed to walk. Then he covered it with small branches and leaves and put dust on it

so that it was impossible to tell where the pit was. He went away and hid. Osebo came prowling in the black night and he stepped into the trap Anansi had prepared and fell to the bottom. Next morning when Anansi went to the pit

he saw the leopard there. Anansi asked the leopard what he was doing there to which the leopard replied that he was fallen into a trap. Anansi promised the leopard to take him out. He bent a tall tree toward the ground so that its top was over the pit
and he tied it that way. Then he tied a rope to the tree and dropped the other end of it into the pit. After that he asked the leopard to tie his tail. And he took his knife and cut the other rope
the one that held the tree bowed to the ground. The tree straightened up with a snap pulling the leopard out of the hole. He hung in the air head downward
twisting and turning. And while he hung this way
Anansi killed him with his weapons.

patterns: “With wisdom and knowledge one can achieve the impossible.” Justify the statement with reference to Kwaku Anansi
the spider.
responses: With wisdom and knowledge one can surely achieve things that seem to be impossible to achieve. In the learnt story
we come to know how a little creature
Anansi

the spider made tree big creatures to fall in his trap. The spider used only his wit and smart tricks to get the three creatures into the trap. What seem to be impossible by the great warriors and chiefs to achieve was achieved by the little creature only by using his wits. It is not about the physical strength but it is about the way one uses its knowledge to achieve things. With right use of the knowledge one can achieve things.

patterns: Why was the passenger thrown out of the lift?
responses: The passenger said “Top” instead of “Top please” to the lift-man and the lift-man felt insulted so he was thrown out of the lift.

patterns: What would happen if we were given the liberty to box people’s ears?
responses: If we were given the liberty to box people’s ears then our fists would never be idle and the gutters of the city would run with blood all day.

patterns: What can the law not compel us to do?
responses: The law cannot compel us to say ‘please’ to others.

patterns: What
according to the author is the difference between physical pain and pain of the wound caused to one’s self-respect?
responses: The difference between physical pain and pain of the wound caused to one’s self-respect is the physical pain may pass away soon and we may not bother about it after some time. But pain of the wound to our self-respect may poison our whole day.

patterns: What is the first and the most important requirement of civility?
responses: The first and the most important requirement of civility is that we should acknowledge a service.

patterns: What did the “polite conductor” do for the author?
responses: The author couldn’t pay the fare because he had forgotten his wallet. The conductor instead of throwing him out of the bus issued him the ticket happily. This was his act of kindness toward the author.

patterns: Who had trampled on the author’s sensitive toe?
responses: The conductor who had issued him the ticket was the same one who trampled on the author’s sensitive toe.

patterns: Why was there a very fine weather on the polite conductor’s bus always?
responses: It was always a very fine weather on the polite conductor’s bus because of his own civility
his conciliatory address and good humoured bearing which infected his passengers.

patterns: What
according to the people is the cause for the dampening of the everyday civilities?
responses: According to the people
the war has had a chilling effect upon those little everyday civilities of behaviour that sweeten the general air.

patterns: Can law enforce civility? How?
responses: The law can be enforced only when someone is physically assaulted/ or physical violence. But the law cannot compel us to say ‘please’ or be polite when we are talking. It cannot compel people on how to say or act. It doesn’t compensate for any moral and intellectual damages. The law cannot become the guardian of our private manners.

patterns: How does bad temper affect one’s life?
responses: Bad temper always has negative impact. It infects other people soon and there is lot of negativity in general. It gets passed from one person to the other and the chain is created. We infect the world with our ill humours. Bad manners probably do more to poison the stream of the general life than all the crimes in the calendar.

patterns: Discuss the importance and effect of good manners.
responses: Good manners are infectious. When someone with good manners talks to us we become happy. It is delight to see people with good manners. There is a certain kind of positivity when people have good manners. A person with good manners lightens his own spirit by lightening others’ spirits. He makes people’s day cheerful and happy. People with good manners are always remembered.

patterns: List out the instances in which the polite conductor showed his civil behaviour. Do you approve of his behaviour? Why?
responses: The first incident when we come across the polite conductor is when he issued the bus ticket to the author when the author had forgotten his wallet and had nothing to pay for the far. In the second incident we saw that he was the same man who trampled the author’s toe. He very apologized the author. Another incident is when he helped the blind man cross the road ad reach the pavement. These three incidents tell how polite and helpful the conductor was. I not only approve his behavior but also wish to be like him in every situation. I like the fact that how he is positive all the time and helps everyone.

patterns: How could the lift man take a polite and effective revenge? Suggest a way to do so?
responses: The liftman would have had a more subtle and effective revenge if he had treated the gentleman who would not say ‘Please’ with elaborate politeness. He would have had the victory
not only over the boor
but over himself
and that is the victory that counts.

patterns: It is easy to be civil at all times period. Do you agree? Why?
responses: Yes

we can always be civil. At least we can try to be civil at all times. If someone is being rude to use we can reply him/her in a polite way. We may lose material advantage but we will always have the spiritual victory. It is important to be calm and have a polite attitude every time. Though it is not compulsory for us to say ‘please’ and ‘thank you’ but these words have big impact. We can use them as a sign of our politeness and courtesy.

patterns: Who were the occupants of the carriage?
responses: The occupants of the carriage were two smaller girls
a small boy
their aunt and a bachelor.

patterns: What questions haunted Cyril when he saw sheep in the field?
responses: Cyril wanted to know why the sheep were driven out the field.

patterns: What made the aunt decide that the bachelor was a hard and unsympathetic man?
responses: The frown on the bachelor’s face was deepening that made the aunt decide that the bachelor was a hard and unsympathetic man

patterns: Who saved the little girl in the aunt’s story?
responses: A number of rescuers who admired the girl’s moral character saved the little girl in the aunt’s story.

patterns: Name the little girl in the bachelor’s story.
responses: The little girl’s name in the bachelor’s story was Bertha.

patterns: What remark of the bachelor’s story created a wave of reaction in favour of the story?
responses: The word horrible in connection with goodness was something new to children which created a wave of reaction among the children.

patterns: How did the prince of the country come to know about Bertha?
responses: Everybody in the country talked about Bertha’s goodness and in this way the prince of the country got to know about her.

patterns: How did the prince of the country honour Bertha?
responses: Bertha’s goodness made the prince of the country to allow her to walk in his park once a week
which was just outside the town. It was a great honor for Bertha because no children were ever allowed in it.

patterns: Why was it a great honour for Bertha being allowed into the Prince’s park?
responses: It was a great honor for Bertha because no children were allowed to go in the park.

patterns: When did Bertha begin to wish that she had never been allowed into the park?
responses: When a wolf started chasing Bertha
it was then Bertha began to wish that she had never been allowed into the park.

patterns: What was the aunt’s reaction to the bachelor’s story?
responses: The aunt felt that the story told by the bachelor was the most improper story to tell to young children. He had undermined the effect of years of careful teaching.

patterns: What qualities of Bertha earned her the three medals?
responses: Bertha had earned three medals which were for obedience
punctuality
and her good behaviour.

patterns: What are the two different thoughts of Bertha on her being extraordinarily good
when she was in the prince’s park?
responses: It was because of Bertha’s goodness that she was allowed to go in the princes’ park. When she was in the park
she thought that it was because of her goodness she was enjoying in the beautiful park. But when she saw an enormous wolf chasing her
she thought that had she not been extraordinarily good
she would have been safe in the town.

patterns: How did the medals earn respect for Bertha
as well as cause her death?
responses: Bertha was extraordinarily good girl. She had earned three medals which were for obedience
punctuality

and her good behaviour. Her medals were pinned on her dress always. Everybody talked about her goodness and in this way the prince of the country got to know about her. He allowed her walk in his park once in a week. No other children were allowed to go in his park and this was an honor for Bertha. Once when she was walking in the park
an enormous wolf started chasing her. She hid behind one of the thickest bushes. The wolf searched and was ready to go

but then he heard the clinking of her medals against each other. The wolf dashed into the bush where Bertha was hiding and dragged her out. The wolf devoured her to the last morsel. Bertha’s medals which were the sign of her respect brought her death.

patterns: The aunt terms the bachelor’s story as the most improper one. Do you agree with her? Give reasons.
responses: The story told by the bachelor ended with a tragic end. We tell children that the good always gets good in return but in the story we get to see that Bertha
who was well-behaved girl
got bad in return. She had tragic end. The children would believe that not always good begets good
so in that way the aunt said that it was the most improper one.

patterns: What elements in the bachelor’s story appealed to the children?
responses: The very first element that appealed to the children were when the bachelor told them Bertha was the word horrible in connection with goodness which was something new to them. Another element was the there were no sheep or clock in the park of the prince. Prince’s mother once had dream the prince would be killed either by sheep or the clock. So they didn’t have any sheep or clock in the park. An enormous wolf killed Bertha when it heard her medals clinking against each other.

patterns: How would the story have ended if Bertha had not pinned the medals on her pinafore?
responses: The story would have ended on a happy note if Bertha had not pinned the medals on her pinafore. It was because of her three medals that made people talk about her. From the people the prince got to know about her goodness. It was because of her goodness that she was allowed in the prince’s park. The three medals that brought her glory and respect also brought her tragic end. If only she had not pinned her medals on her pinafore
she would have been alive and safe.

patterns: What articles did the astrologer carry?
responses: The astrologer carried a dozen cowry shells
a square piece of cloth with obscure mystic charts on it
a notebook
and a bundle of palmyra writing with him.

patterns: What were the different names given by the nuts vendor for his business?
responses: The nuts vendor gave fancy names like “Bombay Ice Cream”
“Delhi Almond
” “Raja’s Delicacy”
etc.

patterns: What kind of life would the astrologer have in his own village?
responses: If the astrologer had continued to live in his own village then he would have carried on the work of his forefathers – namely
tilling the land
living
marrying
and ripening in his cornfield and ancestral home.

patterns: How much did the astrologer charge for his new clients?
responses: The astrologer charged three paise per question for his new clients.

patterns: Why did the astrologer remain silent for at least ten minutes
initially?
responses: The astrologer remain silent for at least ten minutes
initially listening to the people because till then he was provided with enough stuff for a dozen answers and advices.

patterns: What was the signal for the astrologer to bundle up?
responses: The astrologer didn’t have track of time. When the nuts vendor blew out his flare and rose to go
it was the signal for the astrologer to bundle up.

patterns: How much did the astrologer demand from his new client to answer his question?
responses: The astrologer demanded eight annas from his new client to answer his question.

patterns: What did the astrologer ask Guru Nayak to do?
responses: The astrologer asked Guru Nayak to return to his village. He also asked him to rub sacred ash on his forehead and not to travel southward again.

patterns: Why did the astrologer have no light of his own for his business?
responses: The astrologer transacted his business by the light of a flare which crackled and smoked up above the groundnut heap nearby. He didn’t have the municipal lighting. The place was lit up by shop lights. One or two had hissing gaslights
some had naked flares stuck on poles.

patterns: Why did the astrologer close his business when the nuts vendor blew out his flare?
responses: The astrologer didn’t any source of light for himself. When the nuts vendor blew out his flare and rose to go home

it was then the astrologer would close his business. He had to close the business else he would have left him in darkness except for a little shaft of green light which strayed in from somewhere and touched the ground before him.

patterns: How efficient was the astrologer in his business?
responses: The astrologer was not professional. In fact

he was a stranger to the stars. He just said things that would please and astonished his customers. He did that just by practice and guessing. He would let his customers speak for ten minutes so that it would provide him with enough stuff for answers and advices. By letting others speak
he would guess the other things and satisfy his customers.

patterns: Why did the astrologer run away from his village?
responses: When the astrologer was young
he had been drunk; he gambled and quarreled with a man. In that situation the astrologer pushed him into the well and ran away. He escaped from the village to get away from the punishment.

patterns: In the story
do you think the astrologer should be punished for his crime?
responses: What the astrologer did with Guru Nayak was totally wrong and he deserves to be punished. Though Guru Nayak didn’t die but astrologer did make a mistake. The astrologer too feels guilty for his act.

patterns: Describe how the astrologer felt at the end of the story?
responses: The astrologer felt as if a heavy burden had been lifted from him when he got to know that the person whom he pushed into the well was alive. He had been living in guilty ever since he quarrled with the man (Guru Nayak) and pushed him into the well thinking that he was dead. But when the same man came to him asking about the revenge to the man who tried to kill him
it was then that the astrologer got relived because the man was very much alive. At the end of the story
we can see how stress free he becomes.

patterns: Describe the role of fate and chance in the story.
responses: Fate and chance had a big and crucial role in the story. The astrologer quarreled and pushed a man into a well when he was young. He thought that the man was dead and to escape the punishment

he escaped from his village without telling anyone. He started living in another village and started to earn through astrology. As it was written in his faith that he would meet the man whom he tried to kill one day. The man named Guru Nayak came to the astrologer asking him about the man to take revenge from him. But Guru Nayak couldn’t really identify that the man whom he was trying to revenge was the same man reading his palms. As destiny was in the favour of the astrologer he cleverly suggests Guru not to go southwards. The astrologer is much relived by getting to know that the man whom he tried to kill was alive and he was out of the guilt.

patterns: Does the story make you think that all astrologers are false? Write about it.
responses: No
all the astrologers are not false.There are some astrologers who have deep knowledge about their study and predict well.

patterns: How has R.K. Narayan portrayed the attractive appearance of the astrologer?
responses: The astrologer had an attractive personality which attracted many people towards him. His forehead was resplendent with sacred ash and vermilion
and his eyes sparkled with a sharp

abnormal gleam. The power of his eyes was considerably enhanced by their position – placed as they were between the painted forehead and the dark whiskers which streamed down his cheeks: even a half-wit’s eyes would sparkle in such a setting. To crown the effect he wound a saffron-coloured turban round his head.

patterns: Which book took the author into “a dream of flight”?
responses: Charles H.Gibbs Smith’s book – ‘The Invention of the Aeroplane 1799-1909’ took the author into a “a dream of flight.”

patterns: When did the author find the book?
responses: The author found the book amidst a heap of leather bound volumes in an old bookshop.

patterns: What did the book explain?
responses: The book explained in great detail man’s eternal longing and hope that led to innumerable trials
most of which ended as disasters and subsequent experimentation arising from various inventions used for flight before the advent of “Aero plane” as we know of it today.

patterns: How was the bird man dressed to fly?
responses: The bird man tied bat-like wings made from wood and cloth
covered with birds’ feathers.

patterns: What happened to the bird man when he jumped from the tower?
responses: The bird man flexed his shoulders and started beating his arms fast and suddenly jumped out. Instead of flying free in the sky like a bird he tumbled down in inverted manner. He fell in the middle of the crowd in a tangled heap of cloth and feathers and lost his life.

patterns: Who were the first aerial passengers?
responses: A sheep
a hen and a duck placed in the basket of the balloon were the first air passengers.

patterns: Describe the balloon in which the first aerial passengers flew.
responses: Flames leap high from a huge pile of burning wood in the middle of the square. A mammoth globular fabric with its bottom open and decorated with colorful motifs was tied all around with thick ropes. As the sphere filled with hot air and heaved from side to side
four persons cut off the ropes. The crowd watched open-mouthed as the spherical balloon started flying upwards and drifted across the sky. A sheep
a hen and a duck placed in the basket of the balloon became the first air passengers.

patterns: How did Otto Lilienthal make an attempt to fly?
responses: Otto Lilienthal lifted a strange craft built from wood and fabric and brought it out of a shed built atop a big hill. It had two 6 m long bat-like wings on top of one another with a horizontal and a vertical surface behind and a ring shaped frame between the wings. Lilienthal stepped inside the frame and with his arms supporting the ring and ran forward. Within a few steps
Lilienthal’s craft started floating in the air. Hanging beneath
Lilienthal glided for a long distance and touched down at the bottom of the hill.

patterns: How has the author described Orville Wright’s flight into the air?
responses: Wright brothers took their two-winged machine which they had invented to Kitty dunes in North Carolina for its testing. Orville Wright lay prone in the middle over the bottom wing. A small internal combustion engine by his side turned a pair of two-bladed paddle wheels through long bicycle chains. As the engine growled
Wilbur Wright freed the rope holding the machine and it surged forward. Moving about 12 meters per second
the machine suddenly lifted up and flew in the air.

patterns: List out the persons from the lesson who made brave attempts to fly.
responses: In 1853 A.D Sir George Cayley built a boat shaped contraption. In 1891 A.D Otto Lilienthal built a glider. In 1903 The Wright Brothers invented two-winged machine.

patterns: What does the lesson inspire you to do?
responses: The lesson inspires us to do keep trying until we succeed in our life.

patterns: What makes the boy look funny?
responses: The boy’s trousers gave him a curious look of being shorn off with sheep shears. There was always mud on his boots and there were times when he did not smell very sweet. These things made the boy look funny.

patterns: Where are goats kept?
responses: The goats are kept in the pigsty.

patterns: What first made the man and his wife become aware of the smell of the goat kid and the boy?
responses: The clergyman was talking about grace of giving. He also told about the frankincense and myrrh brought by the people. When the clergyman said that what the boy had brought had sweet smell it was the smell of sacrifice for others. It was then the man and his wife become aware of the smell of the goat kid and the boy.

patterns: Why was the boy troubled by the absence of snow on the ground?
responses: The boy always believed that Christmas meant snow on the ground
bells ringing and a moving star. He saw that there was no snow on the ground
no bells ringing and it was then he was troubled.

patterns: Explain the message written on the notice board.
responses: The message written on the notice board meant that no gift was too big or too small. Every type of gift was accepted. Everyone should donate.

patterns: How long did the earthquake last? What was the effect?
responses: The earthquake lasted less than five minutes. It destroyed six hundred and two villages. It destroyed mountain and took many lives.

patterns: Describe the boy’s family.
responses: The boy’s father had died after an illness
just fourteen months ago. His mother took care of them. The boy was the oldest among the three siblings. His brother Nilu was ten. Bhuli
was two-year-old sister. His grandmother also stayed with them.

patterns: How did the army help the people?
responses: The army blasted the rocks and cleared the way. The soldiers began to clear the debris. The soldiers had set up a makeshift camp. Without getting tired the army carried the rescue operation.

patterns: Did Brij return to Panipat ? Why?
responses: Brij and his sister started to live with their uncle. Initially he worked at a dhaba in Panipat. As an expression of gratitude
he would serve free tea to the passengers. A month later he quit his job at the dhaba and returned to Garhwal. There he started his own tea shop.

patterns: How could Brij start his own tea-shop? Where was it?
responses: Brij initially worked at a dhaba near Panipat. He had his own savings which help him start his own tea-shop. His tea-shop was in Garhwal.

patterns: How is Balai related to the writer?
responses: Balai is Rabindranath Tagore’s elder brother’s son. Tagore’s elder had gone to England to study engineering. Balai’s mother had passed away so the responsibility to look after Balai was on Tagore and his wife.

patterns: What kind of a boy was Balai?
responses: Balai was someone who didn’t speak much and would think a lot. He was someone who would get hurt when someone plucked flowers from a tree.It would trouble him when the grass-cutter came to cut the grass.

patterns: What traits in Balai do you admire most?
responses: Balai’s sensitivity toward the nature is what I admire the most in him. Rarely do we come across young people loving the nature so deeply. Balai loved plants very much. He admired the nature.

patterns: Why didn’t Balai want the grass-cutter to cut the plants?
responses: Balai was sensitive towards the nature. He had watched countless wonders in the grass
small creepers
nameless violet and yellow flower and what not. If the grass was cut then all the tiny creatures would be lost so he didn’t want the grass-cutter to cut the plants.

patterns: What do you think is the message in the story?
responses: The message given in the story is that we must learn to respect the nature and its every element. We shouldn’t be insensitive toward the nature and ill-treat it.

intents.tags: smell, hot, food, reaches, several, metres,cold, food
patterns: Give reasons for the following observation:The smell hot sizzling food reaches you several metres away
but to get the smell from cold food you have to go close.
responses: When food is hot
diffusion is more. But in cold food diffusion is slow. Hence to get the smell from cold food we have to go close.

intents.tags: driver,  water, swimming, pool, Which, property, matter
patterns: A driver is able to cut through water in a swimming pool. Which property of matter does this observation show?
responses: This observation shows that particles of matter have kinetic energy.

patterns: What are the characteristics of the particles of matter?
responses: The characteristics of particles are as follows:Particles of matter have space between them.Particles of matter are continuously moving. Particles of matter attract each other.

intents.tags: mass, unit, volume, substance, density, density,mass, /volume, following, order, density,air, chimneys, honey, water, chalk, cotton, iron
patterns: The mass per unit volume of a substance is called density (density = mass /volume) Arrange the following in order of increasing density – air
exhaust from chimneys
honey
water
chalk
cotton and iron.
responses: air
water
exhaust from chimneys
chalk
cotton
honey
iron.

patterns: A gas fills completely the vessel in which it is kept.
responses: Because gas occupies space.

patterns: A gas exerts pressure on the walls of the container.
responses: Because in the gaseous state
the particles move about randomly at high speed. Due to this random movement
the particles hit each other and also the walls of the container. The pressure exerted by the gas is because of this force exerted by gas particles per unit area on the walls of the container.

patterns: A wooden table should be called a solid.
responses: Because in the wooden table particles are closely packed and have less space in between particles.

intents.tags: hand, air, same, solid, block, wood, karate, expert
patterns: We can easily move our hand in air but to do the same through a solid block of wood we need a karate expert.
responses: Air is a gas
it has more space in between particles. But solid block of wood is rigid
hence it is difficult to move our hands through it.

intents.tags: Liquids, lower, density, solids, ice, Boots, water
patterns: Liquids generally have lower density as compared to solids. But you must have observed that ice Boots on water. Find out why?
responses: Density of ice is lesser than water. Hence ice floats on water.

patterns: What is the physical state of water at: 250° Celcius
responses: Water changes to water vapour at 250° C temperature

patterns: What is the physical state of water at: 100° Celcius
responses: Water changes to water vapour at 100°C.

patterns: For any substance
why does the temperature remain constant during the change of state?
responses: Because with the increase of temperature
more number of particles get enough kinetic energy to go into the vapour state. Hence temperature remains constant during the change of state.

patterns: Suggest a method to liquefy atmospheric gases.
responses: L.P.G. which is used for cooking. In the cylinder petrol is in liquid form. When it is lighted it becomes gas.

intents.tags: desert, cooler, cool, hot, dry, day
patterns: Why does a desert cooler cool better on a hot dry day?
responses: The particles of liquid in desert cooler absorb energy from the surrounding to regain the energy lost during evaporation. In summer this is fast. Hence desert cooler cool better in a hot dry day.

intents.tags: water, earthen, pot, matka, cool, summer
patterns: How does the water kept in an earthen pot (matka) become cool during summer?
responses: Water looses its temperature through small pores present in the pot. Hence in an earthen pot (matka) become cool during summer.

patterns: Why does our palm feel cold when we put some acetone or petrol or perfume on it?
responses: Because acetone or petrol or perfume looses their temperature and gain energy by using from surrounding air.

intents.tags: able, hot, tea, milk, saucer, cup
patterns: Why are we able to sip hot tea or milk faster from a saucer rather than a cup.
responses: Because in a saucer
the surface is broad comparing to cup and here rate of evaporation is greater. Hence we are able to sip hot tea or milk faster from a saucer rather than a cup.

patterns: What type of clothes should we wear in summer?
responses: During summer we should wear cotton clothes because cotton absorbs heat quickly and evaporate and helps to cool our body.

patterns: Naphthalene balls disappear with time without leaving any solid.
responses: Because Naphthalene changes its state from solid to gaseous matter. Hence it disappears with time without leaving any solid

patterns: We can get the smell of perfume sitting several meters away.
responses: Because of particles of perfumes diffuse in the air with higher speed and reaches our nose.

intents.tags: following, substances, order, forces, attraction, particles, water, sugar, oxygen
patterns: Arrange the following substances in increasing order of forces of attraction between the particles – water
sugar
oxygen.
responses: Sugar
water
oxygen.

patterns: What is the physical state of water- at 25° C
responses: liquid state

patterns: What is the physical state of water- at  0° C
responses: Ice

patterns: What is the physical state of water- at  100° C
responses: water vapour.

patterns: Water at room temperature is liquid.
responses: Temperature of the room is lesser
so there is no change of state of water
hence it is liquid at room temperature
Pressure is low.

patterns: an iron almirah is a solid at room temperature.
responses: Temperature is less
Pressure is low.

patterns: Why is ice at 273 k. More effective in cooling than water at the same temperature?
responses: Because at 0° C (273 K) particles of water have more energy comparing it to water at the same temperature.

patterns: What produces more severe burns
boiling water or steam.
responses: Steam causes severe burns comparing to boiling water or steam.

patterns: What is meant by substance?
responses: Substance is a pure form of matter.

intents.tags: mixture, kerosene, petrol, difference, boiling, points, more, C, miscible, other
patterns: How will you separate a mixture containing kerosene and petrol (difference in their boiling points is more than 25° C) which are miscible with each other?
responses: To separate a mixture containing kerosene and petrol (difference in their boiling points is more than 25°C)
Fractional distillation method is used.

patterns: Name the technique to separate butter from curd
responses: butter from curd: To separate butter from curd
centrifuge machine can be used or It can be separated by milk churner.

patterns: Name the technique to separate salt from sea-water
responses: salt from seawater: To separate salt from the seawater evaporation method can be used.

patterns: Name the technique to separate camphor from salt.
responses: Comphor from salt: By sublimation method
we can separate camphor from salt.

patterns: What type of mixtures are separated by the technique of crystallization?
responses: By crystallisation method
pure solid in the form of crystals can be separated.

patterns: Explain the following giving examples:Saturated solution.
responses: Saturated solution: At any particular temperature a solution that has dissolved as much solute as it is capable of dissolving is said to be a saturated solution.

patterns: Explain the following giving examples: Pure Substance
responses: Pure substance: A pure substance consists of a single type of particles.

patterns: Explain the following giving examples: Colloid
responses: Colloid: A colloid is a heterogeneous mixture whose size is too small to be individually seen by naked eyes.

patterns: Explain the following giving examples: Suspension

patterns: How will you find the valency of chlorine

responses: i) Chlorine atom has 7 electrons in its outermost shell. Its valency is 7. But it is easier for chlorine to gain one electron instead of losing seven electrons. Hence its valency is determined by subtracting seven electrons from the octet and this gives us a valency of one for chlorine.ii) Sulphur atom has 6 electrons in its outermost shell. But it is easier for sulphur to gain two electrons instead of losing 6 electrons. Hence its valency is determined by subtracting 6 electrons from the octet and this gives us a valency of sulphur is two. iii) Outermost orbit of Megnesium has 2 electrons
hence it has valency two.

patterns: What are the limitations of J.J. Thomson’s model of the atom?
responses: Although Thomson’s model explained that atoms are electrically neutral

patterns: What are the limitations of Rutherford’s model of the atom?
responses: The revolution of the electron in a circular orbit is not expected to be stable. Any particle in the circular orbit would undergo acceleration. During acceleration
charged particles would radiate energy. Thus
the revolving electron would lose energy and finally fall into the nucleus. If this were so
the atom should be highly unstable
and hence matter would not exist in the form that we know
we know that atoms are quite stable.

patterns: Describe Bohr’s model of the atom.
responses: Neils Bohr put forward the following postulates about the model of an atom.Only certain special orbits known as discrete orbits of electrons are allowed inside the atom.While revolving in discrete orbits the electrons do not radiate energy.

patterns: Compare all the proposed models of an atom given in this chapter.
responses: i) Thomson proposed that An atom consists of a positively charged sphere and the electrons are embedded in it.ii) Rutherford put forward the nuclear model of an atom

which had the following features:(a) There is a positively charged centre in an atom called the nucleus. Nearly all the mass of an atom resides in the nucleus.(b) The electrons revolve around the nucleus in circular paths.(c) The size of the nucleus is very small as compared to the size of the atom.iii) Neils Bohr put forward the following postulates about the model of an atom.a) Only certain special orbits known as discrete orbits of electrons are allowed inside the atom.b) While revolving in discrete orbits the electrons do not radiate energy.iv) In 1932

J. Chadwick discovered another sub-atomic particle which had no charge and a mass nearly equal to that of a proton. It was eventually named as a neutron. Neutrons Eire present in the nucleus of all atoms
except hydrogen. Atom has 3 subatomic particles called(a) Protons(b) Neutrons(c) Electrons

intents.tags: rules, writing, distribution, electrons, various, shells, first, eighteen, elements
patterns: Summarise the rules for the writing of distribution of electrons in various shells for the first eighteen elements.
responses: The following rules are followed for writing the number of electrons in different energy levels or shells.i) The maximum number of electrons present in a shell is given by the formula 2n2
where ‘n’ is the orbit number or energy level index
3… Hence the maximum number of electrons in different shells are as follows: First orbit or K-shell will be = 2 × 12 × 2
Second orbit or L shell will be = 2 × 22 = 8
third orbit or M-shell will be = 2 × 32 = 18

fourth orbit or N-shell will be = 2 × 42 = 32 and so on.ii) The maximum number of electrons that can be accommodated in the outermost orbit is 8.iii) Electrons are not accommodated in a given shell unless the inner shells are filled. That is the shells are filled in a step-wise manner.

intents.tags: do, substances, CO2, water, move, cell, Discuss
patterns: How do substances like CO2 and water move in and out of the cell? Discuss.
responses: Some substances like CO2 (Which is cellular waste and requires to be excreted out by the cell) accumulates in high concentrations inside the cell. In the cell’s external environment
the concentration of CO2 is low as compared to that inside the cell. As soon as there is a difference of concentration of CO2 inside and outside a cell
CO2 moves out of the cell
from a region of high concentration
to a region of low concentration outside the cell by the process of diffusion. Similarly

O2 enters the cell by the process of diffusion when the level or concentration of O2 inside the cell decreases. Thus diffusion plays an important role in gasesous exchange between the cells as well as the cell and its external environment.

patterns: Why is the plasma membrane called a selectively permicable membrane?

patterns: What are the major divisions in the Plantae? What is the basis for these divisions?

intents.tags: criteria, divisions, plants, different, criteria, subgroups, animals

even in these few questions that we have asked

or acquire it (animals). Therefore these design features (having a skeleton
for example) are to be used to make sub-groups
rather than making broad groups.

insects

patterns: What are the desirable agronomic characteristics for crop improvements?
responses: Tallness and profuse branching are desirable characters for fodder crops. Deafness is desired in cereals so that less nutrients are consumed by these crops. Thus developing varieties of desired agronomic characters help give higher productivity.

patterns: What are macro-nutrients and why are they called macro-nutrients?

phosphorus

sulphur. They are required in large quantities and are therefore called macro-nutrients.

patterns: How do plants get nutrients?
responses: Nutrients are supplied to plants by air
water and soil. There are sixteen nutrients which are essential for plants. Air supplies carbon and oxygen
hydrogen comes from water and soil supplies the other thirteen nutrients
six are required in large quantities and are therefore called macronutrients. The other seven nutrients are used by plants in small quantities and are therefore called micro-nutrients.

patterns: Why should preventive measures and biological control methods be preferred for protecting crops?
